page.title: 04Roman Influence in Coddenham
page.content: It is said that men have been active in the landscape of Coddenham and Hemingstone for a very long time. The first farmers were 3,700 years ago in the Bronze Age. The Roman town of Combretonium stood slightly to the west of this block. Many Roman and Ancient British roads radiated out from this centre and Roman roads cross Shrubland Park Estate and coins of the Emperor Constantine have been found there. The name of "Shrubland" comes from the Saxon word Scrobe or Scrybe, meaning "Shrub" an indication of the light porous nature of the soil. Coddenham was mentioned in Domesday Book and the name probably was derived from the Anglo-Saxon "Coda's Estate". It was shown as a flourishing township with 75 houses and nearly 400 inhabitants. Coddenham and surrounding area has remained rich and prosperous.
